awd_titl_txt: Tide gate modulation of wetland function: decision support through engineering best practices
awd_abstract_narration:
1702618 (Patterson). Tide gates are valves that are designed to protect life and property but often negatively affect wetlands. This research aims to develop best practices for their operation to maximize protection of people and ecosystem health. In the US, thousands of tide gates are maintained and operated by municipalities and conservation boards. How tide gates are operated affects risks of flooding and fire, and wetlands health, in competing ways. This project will develop new decision support tools for tide gate management using coupled models of water exchange, sediment movement and pollutant loading based on the EPA model QUAL2K, and objective functions for ecosystem services, water quality, and flood and fire risk. By coupling measurements and modeling, this research will move tide gate design and management well beyond prior understanding.

Methodology includes advanced microbial sensors for nitrate, passive contaminant samplers for toxins, and autonomous sensors and vehicles. In cooperation with municipalities in Massachusetts, and a diverse range of stakeholders, tide gate function will be investigated in a large urban coastal marsh with a history of toxin exposure, a smaller urban marsh used recreationally, and a 'pristine' marsh. Decision support tools for tide gate operators will provide directed advice on when and how much to open tide gates under various scenarios, improving public safety and ecosystem health of critical wetlands. Two undergraduates working on 6 month co-ops, and a graduate student, will be trained. Online visualization of tide gate state, water chemistry, biota, and toxins at a dedicated web site will be used to educate managers, the public, and K12 programs. Workshops during years 2-3 will engage the user community during the development of the decision support tools. Public policy MS students will participate in capstone projects to investigate the overlap in regulations among federal, state and local entities to facilitate implementation of best practices, while Civil Engineering undergrads will be involved in required capstone projects and will look for opportunities for both groups to collaborate. This research potentially will increase the sustainability, resilience, and anti-fragility of coastal communities because existing tide gates will be better managed, reducing risk of fire and flooding (and toxin dispersal for some sites), while increasing ecosystem services like essential fish habitat and storm

por.por_cntn:
The goal our research was to develop best practices for tide gate management in coastal wetlands. Tide gates are engineered structures built to prevent flooding of homes and businesses located adjacent to saltmarshes. They work by stopping the flow of water when the incoming tide reaches a certain preset level. The gate prevents the water from rising any higher upstream. The gate opens again during the falling tide.

Because tide gates restrict the flow of salty water into the marsh, they can affect the marsh’s health. For example, if not enough salt water is let into the upper marsh, water quality can suffer, and invasive species that thrive in the freshened water, like the grass Phragmites, can displace the native marsh plants. This can increase fire risk at the end of the growing season when the Phragmites dries out and becomes highly flammable. Changes in water quality and composition of the plants living in the marsh can negatively affect the animals that live there, including birds, fishes, and many aquatic invertebrates. Because saltmarshes serve as nurseries to many species, this can have far-ranging effects on nearby ecosystems, and even commercial fisheries.

We set up sensors at two coastal marshes in Massachusetts: one in the City of Revere and the other in the Town of Marshfield. These sensors measured the local weather and the water quality. We had to develop new methods for sending the data on the upstream side of the gate to our weather station using WiFi telemetry. We were able to monitor the conditions at the tide gates using a smartphone.

We also made measurements in the marsh near tide gates using underwater robots, canoes towing instruments, and specialized sensors like flowmeters that logged lots of data over short periods of time. We also made measurements of pollutants in the marsh around the tide gates, and of the types of plants and animals downstream and upstream of the gates under different conditions.

Several times during our study, the tide gate in Revere experienced operational difficulties, and we were able to study the impact of a temporarily closed gate on the health of the marsh. We found that when a gate is closed for many tidal cycles, the upstream portion rapidly freshens, and that the composition of fishes and invertebrates changes dramatically.

We also found that a key water quality parameter, dissolved nitrogen, increases in the downstream direction toward the ocean. This is worrisome as flooding tides could thus overfertilize the marsh. When saltmarshes receive too much nitrogen this results in “marsh collapse” whereby overfertilized plants become too top heavy, leading to erosion of the marsh channels.

We developed a new metric that tide gate managers can use to gauge tide gate impacts. We call this metric “missing mixing”. It is a conceptual extension of the “pollution exchange coefficient” used by the Environmental Protection Agency and the Army Corps of Engineers to estimate how vulnerable coastal bays and harbors are to pollution. Missing mixing is a proportion that quantifies how much water renewal upstream of the tide gate has been lost because the gate closes during flood tide and doesn’t open again until partway through the ebb tide. The greater this proportion, the higher the probability that the gate will have negative impacts on water quality and ecosystem health. In other words, our metric quantifies mixing that is foregone because of gate closure for part of the tidal cycle.

“Missing mixing” changes over the natural monthly cycle of the tides. Tide gates affect the marsh differently over a month, with greatest negative impacts during spring tides. This finding is significant as our work with stakeholders has taught us that organizations managing tide gates usually use a single setting with respect to gate closure that is set by an upstream tidal elevation that prevents flooding. We discovered that arriving at this setpoint is a complex negotiation between agencies (e.g., NOAA) that issue environmental permits when marshes with tide gates have been restored, and the local municipality operating the tide gate, where flooding potential to abutters is a public safety and liability concern. If operators analyzed tide gate operators using the missing mixing metric, they could use it to improve upstream water quality. They would use the metric to adjust gate closure settings during the neap parts of the monthly tidal cycle to reduce missing mixing.

We engaged stakeholders from federal (NOAA, EPA), and state agencies (Division of Ecological Restoration, MassBays), and municipalities to present our research. Personnel from NOAA and the City of Revere participated in an online field trip (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WTKFBh-yddU), as part of a major conference in ecology and transportation infrastructure. Our project involved five graduate students, eight undergraduates, and was used to teach students in Hong Kong, Iraq, and Northeastern through both remote learning and in-person field trips.
